Fig. 1 Time-courses of the hydrogenolysis of LDPE with Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (0.2 g, ●), Ru(1)/CeO2 (0.2 g, ♦) and Ru(5)/CeO2 (0.05 g, ■). (a) Conversion, (b) wax yield, (c) liquid fuel yield, (d) gas yield. Reaction conditions: catalyst 0.2 or 0.05 g, LDPE (M n: 1,700, M w: 4,000) 3.4 g, H2 5 MPa, 513 K. Research article Chemical recycling of polyethylenes with low gas products by catalytic hydrogenolysis with heterogeneous CeO2-supported Cu-doped Ru catalyst Masazumi Tamura Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Yuna Sasano Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation SMA Hakim Siddiki Masato Akatsuka Formal analysis Data curation Pengru Chen Writing – review & editing Yusuke Kita Writing – review & editing Department of Chemistry and Bioengineering, School of Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, 3-3-138, Sugimoto, Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka 558-8585, Japan Department of Chemistry and Bioengineering School of Engineering Osaka Metropolitan University 3-3-138, Sugimoto, Sumiyoshi-ku Osaka 558-8585 Japan Department of Chemistry and Bioengineering, School of Engineering, Osaka Metropolitan University, 3-3-138, Sugimoto, Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka 558-8585, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Chemical recycling of polyolefins to valuable chemicals has a high potential to mitigate plastic problems and contributes to carbon recycling. In the previous works, we reported that CeO2- and ZrO2-supported Ru (Ru/CeO2 and Ru/ZrO2) catalysts were effective for the hydrogenolysis of polyolefins such as PE, PP, and even waste PE plastics; however, the gas products were formed in ∼10 % yield. The development of effective heterogeneous catalysts that can suppress the formation of cheap gas products, particularly methane, through the incorporation of inexpensive metals into Ru is highly required to achieve high yields of valuable chemicals such as liquid and waxes. Herein, we found that 1 wt% Cu doped 1 wt% Ru/CeO2, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, was an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the suppression of the methane formation (2.3 %, C1–C4 gas: ∼4%) at >99 % conversion in the hydrogenolysis of LDPE at 5 MPa H2, providing the high yield (96 %) of the valuable chemicals (liquid chemicals (C5-C21) + waxes (C ≥22)). The gas selectivity remains low even at a low H2 pressure of 2 MPa. Based on the catalyst characterizations such as XRD, TEM, TEM-EDX, H2-TPR, XAS, and FT-IR analyses, the size of the active metal particles over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is about 1 nm, and the addition of Cu metal into Ru/CeO2 formed Ru-Cu surface alloy on the Ru particles. The formation of the small metal particles and Cu-Ru surface alloy by the addition of inexpensive Cu to Ru decreased the Ru ensemble size to suppress the consecutive C–C bond dissociation of LDPE, leading to low methane and gas yields. Keywords Polyethylene Hydrogenolysis Copper Ruthenium Cerium oxide Alloy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chemical recycling of plastic wastes into high-value-added chemicals has attracted much attention from the background of plastic waste issues such as microplastics and environmental pollution, as well as the increasing need for a carbon-circular society due to the depletion of fossil resources. Among plastics, polyolefins such as polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP) account for about half of all plastics, and recycling them has a significant impact on the chemical recycling of plastic wastes [1–3]. However, the development of effective methods for the selective transformation of polyolefins under mild reaction conditions remains challenging due to the relatively strong C–C bonds of polyolefins. Pyrolysis is the most classical method for the chemical recycling of polyolefins; however, it requires relatively high temperatures (typically > 673 K) and produces a variety of compounds including aromatic compounds and isomerized products, as well as a significant amount of gaseous products [4–7]. As an alternative method, the hydrogenolysis of polyolefins using gaseous H2 has recently gained attention because it can convert polyolefins at milder reaction temperatures (≤573 K) than pyrolysis and provide valuable products with higher selectivity. Various effective heterogeneous catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of polyolefins have been reported [8–13]. Among noble metal species, Pt and Ru are effective metal ones, showing high activity and/or high selectivity for the reaction, and high yields of valuable chemicals (>90 %) were achieved. Ru and Pt metals are generally expensive, and highly active catalysts of inexpensive base metals such as Ni, Co, Cu, and others are desirable. However, considering plastic conversion under low-temperature conditions (≤573 K), Ru or Pt remains the most promising candidate. When comparing the catalytic properties of Pt- and Ru-based catalysts, Ru-based catalysts have higher activity than Pt-based ones. Our group [14] and Román-Leshkov group [15] found that supported Ru catalysts showed activity for the reaction even at 473 K around the same time (∼2021). After the findings, various effective Ru-based catalysts have been developed [16–36], and the summary of effective Ru catalyst systems with high conversion (>90 %) and low gas selectivity (<15 %) is shown in Table S1. Our research group found that Ru-supported catalysts such as CeO2-supported Ru (Ru/CeO2) [14] and ZrO2-supported Ru (Ru/ZrO2) [16] catalysts showed higher activity than other noble metal catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of polyethylenes at comparatively low reaction temperatures (473–513 K), providing valuable chemicals such as liquid fuels (C5–C21) and waxes (C22–C45) in high yields (∼90 %) by suppressing the formation of gas products (C1–C4). The isomerization of produced alkanes was suppressed over these Ru catalysts, and the main products were linear alkanes [14]. The Román-Leshkov group reported carbon-supported Ru (Ru/C) catalyst was effective for the hydrogenolysis of polyolefines to liquid alkanes even at 473 K [15], however, the gas product, mainly methane, was over 50 %. One of the biggest problems in our catalyst systems of Ru/CeO2 and Ru/ZrO2 is the formation of non-valuable gas products, particularly methane, and the yield of the gas products is about 10 % at complete conversion [14,16]. Gas products are generally cheaper than liquid chemicals and waxes. Among valuable chemicals, lubricating oils (C15–C26) and waxes such as paraffin waxes (around C20 ∼ C40) are higher value-added products than liquid chemicals such as jet oils, gasoline oils and naphtha, while liquid chemicals are suitable for large-scale processing. Therefore, long alkanes (>C21) are one of the desirable target compounds. The gas yield over our Ru catalysts is comparatively low compared with the reported other Ru catalysts [15,20,21,23,28,32–37]. However, the development of more effective Ru catalysts that can suppress the formation of gas products, particularly methane formation, is highly desirable to make the most of the carbon from polyolefins. Suppressing gas formation including methane in the hydrogenolysis of polyolefins over heterogeneous catalysts is generally difficult due to the non-uniformity of the active site. Therefore, a more precise design of the active sites is required in heterogeneous catalysts. As a design guideline for heterogeneous catalysts to decrease gas formation, our previous research on Ru-based catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of polyethylenes has shown that smaller Ru particles are effective [16]. Moreover, according to other works [18,21], methane, a main gas product, is formed by the successive C–C bond dissociation over the Ru metal ensemble of Ru particles after the hydrogenolysis of the C–C bonds of polyethylenes. One possible solution for the suppression of methane formation is to suppress the continuous C–C bond hydrogenolysis of PE on the catalyst surface by the promotion of H2 supply to Ru metal sites to facilitate the hydrogenation of methylene adspecies on the metal surface. Szanyi et al. demonstrated that in the hydrogenolysis of polyethylene using a Ru/C catalyst, increasing the hydrogen pressure can effectively suppress methane formation [19], and ∼3 % yield of methane and ∼10 % yield of gas products were achieved at 8 MPa H2. An alternative solution is controlling the size of the Ru ensemble. Vlachos and co-workers have also been actively engaged in the development of effective Ru catalysts for the suppression of methane formation. They have found that reducible metal oxide-modified ZrO2 supported Ru catalysts, Ru/MOx-ZrO2 (M = W, V, Mo) catalysts, could suppress the formation of gas products, particularly methane [18], via the reverse hydrogen spillover by metal oxides, however, the gas yields were around 15 % (methane: 8 ∼ 10 %) at high conversion levels. L. Wang and J. Chen recently reported that the CeO2-supported Ru single-atom catalyst can dramatically suppress the gas formation (about 3.1 % yield, methane 2.2 %) at 98 % conversion in the hydrogenolysis of PE [22]. In this catalyst system, the Ru single-atom catalyst was achieved by reducing the Ru loading amount to 0.2 wt%, making it challenging to use the catalyst on an industrial scale. Moreover, in our manuscript under submission, the formation of RuPt alloy enabled the suppression of the gas formation, particularly methane formation (2 ∼ 3.2 %), by the dilution of Ru metals with the addition of Pt metals and the reduction of the Ru ensemble size [23,24]. However, the noble metals loading (Pt and Ru) is around 4 ∼ 5 wt%, which requires a substantial amount of precious metals. On the other hand, Ni aluminate catalyst was also reported to be effective for the suppression of methane formation (<5%) by appropriately reducing the Ni species [25]. However, the high temperature of 623 K was required to achieve a reasonable level of activity due to the low activity of Ni metals. Therefore, it is necessary to design a new catalytic system that can reduce gas formation, particularly methane formation, even at low H2 pressures using lower noble metal amounts combined with more cost-effective metal species. We envisioned that Ru ensemble size could be decreased by reducing the Ru particle size and introducing an inexpensive second metal to Ru metal particles, leading to low methane formation. We found that decreasing the Ru loading amount (1 wt%) in Ru/CeO2 and adding inexpensive Cu metal into Ru/CeO2 effectively suppressed the gas formation, particularly methane formation, in the hydrogenolysis of polyethylenes even at a low H2 pressure of 2 MPa. 1 wt% Cu-doped 1 wt% Ru/CeO2 catalyst was the efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the suppression of gas formation (∼4.3 % yield), particularly methane formation (2.3 % yield) at >99 % conversion, leading to the high-yield synthesis of valuable chemicals (96 %, wax + liquid chemicals) in the hydrogenolysis of LDPE. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Used polyolefins are commercially available: Low-density polyethylene (LDPE, M n: 1,700, M w: 4,000, Sigma Aldrich; M n: 3,000,000 ∼6,000,000, Sigma Aldrich), Linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE, melt index 1.0 g/10 min (463 K/2.16 kg, Sigma Aldrich), High-density polyethylene (HDPE, melt index 12 g/10 min (463 K/2.16 kg). LDPE with M n of ∼1,700 was used as a standard substrate. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Ru(x)/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method, where x (x = 0.5–5) means the Ru loading amount (wt%). A desired amount of Ru(NO)(NO3)3-x(OH)x in diluted nitric acid (Sigma Aldrich, Ru: 1.5 wt%) was impregnated in CeO2 (Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo, HS, obtained by calcination at 1173 K for 3 h, 26.1 m2 g−1). After evaporating the solvent, the obtained wet catalysts were dried at 383 K for 12 h, providing dried catalysts. The dried catalysts were heated in the N2 flow at 573 K for 1 h as pretreatment. M(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts (M = Cu, Co, Ni, Zn, Fe) were prepared by the sequential impregnation method, where x is the loading amount of M. A desired amount of metal (M) precursors was impregnated in the dried Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst prepared by the above method. After evaporating the solvent, the obtained wet catalysts were dried at 383 K for 12 h, followed by heating in the N2 flow at 573 K for 1 h as pretreatment. Used metal precursors are as follows: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, purity: 99 %), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, purity: 99.9 %), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, purity: 98 %), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, purity: 99.9 %), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, purity: 99 %). 2.3 Activity tests for hydrogenolysis of polyethylenes Activity tests of commercial PEs were performed in a 190 ml stainless steel autoclave reactor. The catalyst and substrate were put into a glass cylinder with a glass-coated magnetic spinner, and the cylinder was set in the autoclave reactor. After being sealed, the reactor was purged with H2 three times and pressured to 3 MPa by H2 at room temperature, followed by heating to 513 K at a stirring rate of 450 rpm. In the case of 513 K, the heating time was about 1 h, and the H2 pressure reached 5 MP. The time when the temperature reached the desired one was defined as 0 h reaction time. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature in a water bath. Gas products were transferred to a 10 L aluminum gas bag, and liquid products were transferred to a 30 mL glass vial. 20 mL of mesitylene (Wako Pure Chemicals Industries) was used as a washing solvent to collect the liquid phase. The residual solid was weighed after suction filtration. The products were analyzed with GC (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The DB-1 capillary column (Agilent J&W) was used for separation. 80 μL of dichloromethane (Wako Pure Chemicals Industries) was added as an internal standard into the gas phase collected in the gas bag, and 200 μL of the gas sample was injected into GC. About 100 mg of 9,10-dihydroanthracene (Tokyo Chemical Industry) was added as an internal standard into the liquid phase, and 1.0 μL of the liquid sample was injected into GC. The qualitative analysis of products was performed with GC–MS (Shimadzu QP-5050) by EI and CI modes. The maximum carbon number that can be analyzed by GC-FID is 45 due to the high boiling point of products, and product distribution was decided as follows: gas (C1–C4), liquid fuel (C5–C21), wax (C22–C45). The conversion and yield were calculated using the formulas shown below. A residual solid after the reaction is assumed to contain an unreacted substrate and a catalyst, although the unreacted substrate may partially react. The amount of the unreacted substrate was calculated by subtracting the introduced catalyst amount from the weight of the residual solid. The carbon balance in each experiment was basically within the experimental error (±10 %). C o n v e r s i o n [ % ] = A m o u n t o f s u b s t r a t e i n p u t g - A m o u n t o f u n r e a c t e d s u b s t r a t e g A m o u n t o f s u b s t r a t e i n p u t g × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y [ % - C ] = A m o u n t o f e a c h p r o d u c t m o l - C ∑ A m o u n t o f p r o d u c t s m o l - C × 100 Y i e l d [ % - C ] = C o n v e r s i o n [ - ] × S e l e c t i v i t y [ - ] × 100 The reusability of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 in hydrogenolysis of LDPE (M n: 1,700; M w: 4,000) was tested as follows: First, we conducted the standard activity test with a fresh catalyst. Next, we collected all the reaction mixture using mesitylene as a washing solvent. The used catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with mesitylene (1 mL) three times, and dried in air 383 K for 12 h. An adequate amount of the catalysts used for the next reaction test was obtained by conducting some tests. The next reaction was conducted under the same reaction conditions using the collected catalysts. 2.4 Characterization methods The specific surface area of catalysts was measured with the BET method (N2 adsorption) using BELSORP MiniX (MicrotracBEL Corp.). Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was measured with a multitype ICP emission spectrometer (ICPE-9800, Shimadzu). The samples were prepared as follows: The liquid phase reaction mixture was washed three times with 1 M HNO3 (5 mL). The combined aqueous layers were diluted to 20 mL in a volumetric flask. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a diffractometer (Rigaku MiniFlex-600) with Cu Kα (λ = 0.154 nm, 45 kV, 40 mA) radiation. Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) was measured with BELCAT-BELMASS II (MicrotracBEL Corp.). The sample amount was about 100 mg. The sample was heated under 4.93 % H2/Ar with 30 mL/min flow rate from 308 K to 1273 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. Scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) images were taken with a JEOL JEM-ARM200F. The sample was dispersed in ethanol and placed on a Cu grid in an air atmosphere. FT-IR spectra of CO adsorption were recorded with FT/IR-6700 (JASCO Corporation) with a resolution of 4 cm−1 in a transition mode using an in situ cell with CaF2 windows. The catalyst sample, which was obtained after the pretreatment (N2 flow at 573 K for 1 h), was pressed into a self-supporting disk (20 mm diameter, ∼50 mg). The sample disk was put into the IR cell that was connected to the gas flow system and reduced with flowing 5 % H2/Ar (30 ml/min) at 513 K for 10 min. After evacuation of H2 and cooling, 10 % CO/He (30 ml/min) was introduced into the catalyst sample at room temperature for 30 min, and the corresponding FT-IR spectra were recorded under 10 % CO/He flow. After that, the 10 % CO/He flow was switched to Ar flow (30 ml/min) to evacuate gaseous CO for 30 min, and CO adspecies were recorded under Ar. X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) was conducted at the BL01B1 station at SPring-8 with the approval of the Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JASRI), Proposal No 2024A1931. The storage ring was operated at 8 GeV, and a Si (111) single crystal was used to obtain a monochromatic X-ray beam. For Ru K-edge measurement, two ion chambers for I0 and I were filled with 100 % Ar and 80 % Ar + 20 % Kr, respectively. For Cu K-edge measurement, two ion chambers for I0 and I were filled with 100 % N2 and 30 % Ar + 70 % Kr, respectively. For the used catalyst, the catalyst sample after the reaction was transferred from the autoclave to the measurement cell in N2 atmosphere. The EXAFS and XANES data were collected in a transmission or fluorescence mode. For EXAFS analysis, the oscillation was first extracted from the EXAFS data using a spline smoothing method [38]. The edge jumps were from 0.3 to 0.4. Fourier transform of the k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillation from the k space to the r space was performed over the range of 30–120 nm−1 to obtain a radial distribution function. The inversely Fourier-filtered data were analyzed using a usual curve-fitting method [39,40]. For curve-fitting analysis, the empirical phase shift and amplitude functions for the Ru-Ru bond were extracted from data from Ru powder. The empirical phase shift and amplitude functions for the Cu-Cu bond were extracted from data from Cu foil. Analysis of EXAFS data was performed using a computer program (REX2000, ver. 2.6; Rigaku Corp.). Hanning window with Δk = 0.05 was applied before Fourier transformation in the analysis of Ru/CeO2. We calculated the number of independent parameters for the curve-fitting analysis of EXAFS as follows: IP = (2ΔkΔR/π) + 2 [41], and confirmed that the value (9.6) was sufficiently larger than the number of fitted parameters (≤4) in the curve fitting for all simulations. Error bars for each parameter were estimated by stepping each parameter while optimizing the other parameters until the residual factor became two times its minimum value [42]. 3 Catalyst screening and catalytic performance At first, the effect of Ru loading amount in Ru/CeO2 catalysts was investigated in the hydrogenolysis of low-density polyethylene (LDPE, M n = 1,700, M w = 4,000) (Table 1 ) with a CeO2 support calcined at 1173 K, which temperature is determined in terms of the activity by the screening of the calcination temperature of CeO2 (Table S2) and the tendency was already reported in our previous work [16]. Notice that the reaction temperature was set to 513 K with the conversion of various plastics in mind because the fluidity of PEs can affect the reaction, and at lower temperatures (∼473 K), the low fluidity can cause a significant decrease in reactivity [16]. The conversions were adjusted to 90 ∼ 100 % to compare the selectivities properly by changing the reaction time and catalyst amount. The selectivity to liquid chemicals is higher than waxes at all Ru loading amounts. The selectivity to gas products decreased with the decrease in the Ru loading amounts up to 1 wt% (Table 1, entries 1–5), and it was similar at lower Ru loading amounts (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). The conversion rates were calculated to evaluate these catalysts' activity as follows: Conversion rate (gLDPE gRu −1h−1) = (Converted LDPE (g)) / (Total Ru metal (g)) / (Reaction time (h)). Ru(5)/CeO2 showed the highest conversion rate (430 h−1) (Table 1, entry 1), and the rate decreased with the decrease of the Ru loading amounts. Regarding the selectivity of gas products and conversion rate, Ru(1)/CeO2 was selected for the following studies, although the conversion rate is about half of the Ru(5)/CeO2. The effect of the addition of second metals into Ru(1)/CeO2 was investigated in the hydrogenolysis of LDPE at 513 K and 24 h as a model reaction (Table 2 ). Considering the metal costs, base metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn were selected as the second metal. The loading amount of the second metal is 1 wt%. The conversions with Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Co(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts at 24 h were high (93->99 %) (entries 1,3 and 4). Focusing on the selectivity to wax products (C22-45), the selectivity over Ru(1)/CeO2 was quite low (13 %) compared with those of other catalysts (36–61 %) and that to gas products (C1-4) was high (21 %). These results suggest that the hydrogenolysis of the produced waxes and liquid products proceeded considerably according to the behavior of the hydrogenolysis of LDPE over the Ru/CeO2 catalyst in our previous report [14]. To compare the selectivity more fairly, we also showed the result of 96 % conversion with Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst by shortening the reaction times from 24 h to 8 h (entry 2). The selectivity of waxes increased to 35 %, and that of gas products decreased to 5.4 %. Therefore, adding the second metal decreased the activity of Ru(1)/CeO2. Ni-added Ru/CeO2 catalyst showed moderate conversion (46 %) at 24 h (entry 5), and Zn and Fe-added Ru/CeO2 catalysts showed almost no activity (entries 6 and 7). The activity order was as follows: Ru(1)/CeO2 > Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 ≈ Co(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 > Ni(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 ≫ Zn(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Fe(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2. As for the selectivity to gas products (C1-4), the Cu-doped Ru/CeO2 showed lower selectivity (4.2 %) than Ru(1)/CeO2, Co(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Ni(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts (5.3–5.6 %) at a similar conversion level (93–97 %, entries 2–5). Cu(1)/CeO2 was also tested in the same reaction. However, the conversion was nearly zero (entry 8), indicating that Cu species has no activity for the reaction under the present reaction conditions. These results indicate that the addition of Cu to Ru/CeO2 was effective in decreasing the gas products. Next, the effect of Cu loading amount (x) in Cu(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts was studied with the same reaction (Table 3 ). At 24 h, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(0.1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 showed full conversion (>99 %) (entries 2 and 4). However, the conversion decreased with increasing the Cu loading amount (entries 4–8). To compare the selectivity precisely, we adjusted the conversions with Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(0.1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 to be below 100 % by shortening the reaction time (entries 1 and 3), and the selectivity to gas products was compared below 100 % conversion. The selectivity decreased from 5.4 to 4.2 %, with the increase in the Cu loading amount to 1 wt% (entries 1, 3, and 5), and similar at higher Cu loading amounts (entries 5–7). In terms of the selectivity to gas products, the 1 wt% Cu-loaded Ru(1)/CeO2 (Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2) was the effective catalyst for the reaction. The effect of H2 pressure was investigated with Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, and the results were compared (Tables 4 and 6 ). The details of the gas selectivity are also shown in Tables 5 and 7 . The standard H2 pressure is 5 MPa at 513 K. The tendency of catalytic performance with Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is different from that with Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, and the difference of conversions and selectivities at low H2 pressures (1 and 2 MPa) is significant. In the case of Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (Table 4), the conversion increased from 36 to 96 % with increasing the H2 pressure from 1 to 5 MPa (Table 4, entries 1–4) and decreased at higher H2 pressures of 6 and 8 MPa (Table 4, entries 5 and 6). The selectivity of gas products (C1-4) increased from 4.5 % to 16 % with the decrease in H2 pressure from 8 to 1 MPa (Table 4, entries 1–6). This tendency is similar to that with Ru(5)/CeO2 catalyst [14]: The conversion increase in the H2 pressures from 1 to 5 MPa can be interpreted by the increase of the supply of H species to the surface of Ru metals with increasing the H2 pressure, considering that the hydrogenolysis of the C–C bonds in polyethylenes by H species on Ru metals is the rate-determining step. In contrast, the conversion decrease at higher H2 pressures (5–8 MPa) can be explained by the higher amount of the surface H species on Ru metal particles, which suppresses the access of LDPE and decreases the conversion [20]. Focusing on the details of the gas selectivity (Table 5), the selectivities to C2-4 gases were almost the same at any H2 pressures, but that to methane (C1) increased with decreasing H2 pressures. Therefore, the H2 pressure mainly has a significant influence on the selectivity of methane over Ru(1)/CeO2. On the other hand, in the case of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (Table 6), the conversion decreased from 97 to 37 % with the increase in the H2 pressures from 5 to 8 MPa (Table 6, entries 4–6); however, the conversions maintained high (85–87 %) at the range of 1–3.5 MPa H2 (Table 6, entries 1–3). This result suggests that the amount of active H species over Ru metals was not changed at 1–3.5 MPa H2. It is well-known that Cu metals can induce hydrogen spillover over CeO2 [43,44]. H adspecies generated from H2 on the Cu metals of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst will spill over onto the CeO2 support to reach Ru metals. Therefore, one possible explanation for the result is that Cu metals supplied H species to Ru metals by the hydrogen spillover to replenish the decreased H species over Ru metals due to the lower pressures, leading to the high conversion at a low H2 pressure of 1 MPa. On the other hand, the decrease in the conversion at high H2 pressure over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst may be due to the excess hydrogen supply to Ru metals by hydrogen spillover from Cu metals, suppressing the access of PEs to Ru metals. The selectivity of the gas products was low and did not so change (3.8–4.7 %) at 2–8 MPa (Table 6, entries 2–6). This tendency is quite different from the case of Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, where the selectivity increased with the decrease of H2 pressures from 5 to 2 MPa (Table 4, entries 2–4). However, the gas selectivity at 1 MPa H2 over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst was high (14 %) (Table 6, entry 1). As for the details of the gas selectivity (Table 7), similar to the case of Ru(1), the selectivity of C2–4 gases shows little change with varying H2 pressures, while the selectivity of methane significantly increases when the pressure reaches 1 MPa. Therefore, as previously discussed, the difference in the H2 pressure dependence can be explained by the difference in hydrogen concentration on the catalyst surface caused by the addition of copper. As above, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst can facilitate the reaction smoothly even at a low hydrogen pressure of 1 MPa, however, when considering a reaction with a low gas selectivity, it is also possible to conduct the reaction at 2 MPa H2. These results show the high potential of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst at low H2 pressures, and the Cu-addition will enhance the H2 supply to the active Ru sites, leading to high activity and low selectivity to gas products even at a low H2 pressure of 2 MPa. The time courses of LDPE hydrogenolysis were investigated with Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2, and Ru(5)/CeO2 catalysts, and the reaction behavior and each product yield were compared (Fig. 1 , Table S3). The figures of the time courses for each catalyst are shown in Fig. S1. The conversions smoothly increased with increasing the reaction time over all the catalysts (Fig. 1(a)), the activities of Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts were higher than that of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst as described above (Tables 1 and 2). As for the product formation behavior, overall, all catalysts exhibited a similar trend: wax products were formed first (Fig. 1(b)), and subsequently, as the wax yield decreased, the yield of liquid fuels increased (Fig. 1(c)), followed by an increase in gas yield (Fig. 1(d)). Focusing on the maximum wax yield (Fig. 1(b)), the highest yield of 45 % was obtained by the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, which is higher than that of the Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts. On the other hand, looking at the liquid fuel yield (Fig. 1(c)), the maximum yield over the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is lower than that of the Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts. These results suggest that Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst suppressed the depolymerization of LDPE to lower alkanes compared to the Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts. Furthermore, focusing on the behavior of gas yield (Fig. 1(d)), for the Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, the gas yield increases exponentially over long reaction times (see inset in Fig. 1(d)), whereas for the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, the increase of gas yield remains relatively linear even at longer reaction times. Therefore, the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst effectively suppressed the gas formation even at high conversion levels, leading to low gas selectivity at 100 % conversion. The maximum yield of valuable chemicals (liquid fuels and waxes) reached 96 % (liquid fuels: 58 % and waxes: 38 %) at 26 h over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, and the formation of the gas product was low (4.3 %, methane 2.3 %). The reaction over Ru(1)/CeO2 reached >99 % conversion at 12 h, and the yields of valuable chemicals and gas products were 92 % (liquid fuels: 74 % and waxes: 18 %) and 7.7 % (methane 4.3 %), respectively. The reaction over Ru(5)/CeO2 reached >99 % conversion at 4 h, and the yields of valuable chemicals and gas products were 88 % (liquid fuels: 61 % and waxes: 27 %) and 12 % (methane 9.2 %), respectively. The yield of valuable chemicals of Ru(5)/CeO2 is a little lower than that (92 %) in our previous work [14], which will be mainly due to the difference in the calcination temperatures of CeO2 support (This work: 1173 K, previous work: 873 K). Ru(1)-Cu(1)/CeO2 provided higher valuable chemicals (96 %), particularly yields of waxes, than that of Ru(1)/CeO2 and Ru(5)/CeO2 catalysts, and the yield of gas products was lower (4.3 %, methane 2.3 %). Therefore, Ru(1)-Cu(1)/CeO2 was the effective catalyst for the reaction (a) in Fig. 1. To clarify the difference between the products over Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2, and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, the product yields, distribution, and branching ratio of C6 products were compared. At first, the product yields of gases, liquid chemicals and waxes at the point of reaching exactly 100 % conversion were compared, as shown in Fig. 2 (a) and Table S4 (The data are quoted in Fig. 1), given the importance of comparing gas yields under conditions that afford high yields of valuable chemicals. As described above, the yield of gas products decreased with the decrease of Ru loading amount from 5 wt% to 1 wt% (12 %–7.7 %) and decreased with the addition of Cu species into the Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (7.7 %–4.3 %). The distribution of products was scrutinized. The detailed product distributions over these catalysts are roughly similar (Fig. S2), while the distribution of gas yields was largely changed (Fig. 2(b)). By decreasing the Ru loading amount from 5 to 1 wt%, methane yield was mainly decreased (methane ratio in total gas products: 77 %–56 %), while ethane, propane, and butane yields were not changed much. Moreover, by the addition of Cu species to Ru(1)/CeO2, methane and other gas products were decreased equally (methane ratio in total gas: 56 %–53 %). Therefore, the decrease in the Ru loading amount mainly influenced the formation of methane, and the addition of Cu species influenced the formation of all gas products. Next, the gas selectivity at a low conversion level (∼20 %) with these catalysts was compared (Table S3). The gas selectivity with the Ru(5)/CeO2 catalyst was 16 % (methane 13 %), whereas it was lower—5.5 % (methane 4.5 %) and 5.2 % (methane 3.9 %), respectively—with the Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, and the gas and methane selectivity over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is a little lower than that over Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst. When the gas selectivity was compared at a conversion level of approximately 70–90 %, the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Ru(5)/CeO2 catalysts showed selectivities of 3.8 % (@73 % conv.), 4.5 % (@87 % conv.) and 12 % (@76 % conv.), respectively, following the same trend observed at the point of reaching exactly 100 % conversion (Fig. 2). To gain further insight into the gas formation trend, we focused on the susceptibility of the terminal C–C bond cleavage in LDPE. Since methane, the main component of the gas products, is formed through the cleavage of the terminal C–C bonds in alkanes, a lower ratio of terminal C–C bond cleavage relative to total C–C bond cleavage results in lower methane formation. The terminal C–C bond cleavage ratio was defined as terminal C–C bond cleavage amount (mmol) / total C–C bond cleavage amount (mmol) and calculated by dividing the formation of formed CH4 amount (mmol) by the total H2 consumption amount (mmol), where H2 consumption amount was calculated by subtracting the introduced LDPE amount (mmol) from the total amount of products (mmol). The terminal C–C bond cleavage ratio was plotted as a function of the conversion for Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The terminal C–C bond cleavage ratio was lower in the following order: Ru(5)/CeO2 > Ru(1)/CeO2 > Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, even at low conversion levels. These results indicate that the lower Ru loading amount and the introduction of Cu to Ru more suppressed the cleavage of the terminal C–C bonds in LDPE. The reason for that will be discussed based on the catalyst structure and reaction mechanism. The distribution of C6 products was evaluated because C6 products including C6 isomers can be detected and assigned by GC and GC–MS (Table S5). n-Hexane was mainly produced, and the ratio of n-hexane to C6 isomers (branched C6 products) is over 98 % over all the catalysts, which is similar tendency to that of our previous works on hydrogenolysis of LDPE over Ru catalyst [14]. These results indicate that the isomerization of linear alkanes is difficult to occur over these catalysts, and the tendency was not changed by the Ru loading amount and the Cu addition. The reusability of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst was investigated under the reaction conditions where the conversion is near 100 % (Fig. 4 , Table S6). The conversions were not changed even in the fourth usage, and the selectivity to products was not so changed. Remarkably, the selectivity to gas products was always low (3.8–4.6 %). Moreover, the leaching amount of Ru and Cu species in the reaction mixture after the reaction was measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), showing that it is below 0.1 % (Table S7). The Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts after the first and the second reaction were analyzed by XRD (Fig. S3). The only signals due to CeO2 support were observed, and there are no signals due to Ru metal and Cu metals. Therefore, these metal species are highly dispersed on CeO2 support during the reaction, and aggregation of these metals did not occur. Therefore, the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 is a reusable heterogeneous catalyst without losing activity and selectivity. The high stability will be derived from the strong interaction between Ru and Cu metals and CeO2 [45,46] as well as the relatively low reaction temperature (513 K) and hydrophobic reaction media. Finally, the scope of polyethylenes was investigated with Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (Table 8 ). The reactivity of LDPE with a higher molecular weight (M n=(3–6) × 106) was also high (entry 2), and 12 h reaction time was enough for the high conversion (95 %), providing the valuable chemicals in a high yield (95 %) with low selectivity to gas products. These results indicate that the reactivity was not so affected by the molecular weights. Liner LDPE (LLDPE) with high molecular weight (M n = 184,000) required a little longer reaction time (36 h) for the high conversion (entry 3) than LDPEs. The gas selectivity was higher than that of LDPE, which is due to the branched structure of LLDPE. Finally, the reactivity of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) with M w = 72,000 was investigated (entry 4). The reactivity was similar to or slightly lower than that of the standard LDPE (entry 1), and the selectivity to gas products was higher than that of the standard LDPE. The selectivity difference is similar to the cases with Ru/CeO2 and Ru/ZrO2 catalysts in our previous reports [14,16]. Therefore, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is applicable to the hydrogenolysis of various LDPEs. 4 Catalyst characterization and proposed active site and reaction mechanism To clarify the reason for the low selectivity of gas products over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst in hydrogenolysis of LDPE, we characterized relevant catalysts using various methods such as H2-TPR, XRD, TEM, XAS and CO adsorption by FT-IR. At first, H2-TPR analyses were conducted with Cu(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(1)/CeO2 and CeO2, and the results are shown in Fig. S4 and Table S8. Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 show a main signal around 350 K and a broad signal at higher temperatures (Fig. S4(b),(c)), and the reduction degrees of Ru species below 513 K (reaction temperature) are calculated to be >99 % (Table S8). Cu(1)/CeO2 shows the two main signals at 435 and 484 K (Fig. S4(d)), and the reduction degree of Cu species is calculated to be >99 % (Table S8). Cu(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts show warped signals, whose peaks are at higher temperatures than that of Ru(1)/CeO2 and are at lower temperatures than that of Cu(1)/CeO2. The reduction degrees of Ru and Cu species are estimated to be >99 % (Table S8). These results indicate that Ru metals accelerated the reduction of Cu species to Cu metals. On the other hand, the peak of the signals of Cu(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts shifted to higher temperatures with the increase in the Cu loading amount, suggesting that Cu metals suppressed the reduction of Ru species. These results suggest that Ru and Cu metals tightly interacted with each other. On the other hand, the effect of the CeO2 support on the reduction of metals is also important. According to our previous study on Ru/CeO2 catalysts for hydrogenolysis reactions [14,47], the reduction of Ru species was promoted when using CeO2 as the support compared to other metal oxide supports, which was confirmed by H2-TPR. Additionally, according to the previous works on Cu/CeO2 catalysts for hydrogenation reactions [48,49], the reduction of Cu species is significantly enhanced compared to SiO2 support. Therefore, the promoting effect of CeO2 on the reduction of Ru and Cu metals enabled the complete reduction of Ru and Cu species at the reaction temperature of 513 K, even though the reduction of Ru species may be somewhat suppressed by the addition of Cu species. As a result, Ru and Cu can become metals, leading to the formation of Ru-Cu alloy, which is discussed later. In addition, H2-TPR analyses were conducted with second metal-added Ru/CeO2 catalysts to investigate the state of the added metals (Fig. S5 and Table S9). Fe and Zn species were hardly reduced, Ni and Co species were partially reduced, and Cu species were completely reduced at the reaction temperature of 513 K (reduction degrees of various Cu-Ru/CeO2 catalysts are discussed later). The conversion depended on the reduction degree of the second metal species to some extent and tended to increase with increasing the reduction degrees. Based on our previous study on catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of LDPE [14], we have shown that catalysts such as NiOx/CeO2 and CoOx/CeO2, even after pre-reduction at 973 K, exhibit no activity for the reaction. These results indicate that metallic Ni or Co on CeO2 does not significantly contribute to catalytic activity. Therefore, these metal species are not considered to serve as active sites for the hydrogenolysis. Instead, they can be poison metal species by adsorbing onto the Ru metal surface as metal oxides or metallic species, covering the Ru active sites and thereby diminishing the catalytic activity. The differences in activity arise from variations in the extent of coverage on the Ru surface, which depend on the type of metal species added. Further investigation will be required to clarify the catalyst structures of these catalysts and the cause of the deactivation. The XRD patterns of various Cu(x)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts were also investigated (Fig. S6). Strong signals at 28.6, 33.1, 47.6, 56.4, 59.2, and 69.5° were observed in all patterns, which can be assigned to CeO2. In the case of Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. S6(e)), small signals due to LDPE were also observed because the conversion was not complete (84 %, entry 6 in Table 2). The expanded spectra in the range of 35-55° are shown in Fig. S7(II). There were no signals due to Ru metal (Typical Ru metal signals: 38.4, 42.1, 44.0, 58.3, and 78.4°, JCPDS No. 06–0663) and Cu metal (Typical Cu metal signals: 43.3, 50.4, 74.1, JCPDS No. 04–0836), although the small signals due to LDPE were also observed (Fig. S7(II)-(a)). These results suggest that Ru and Cu metal species were highly dispersed on CeO2 support. TEM images of Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts after reaction are shown in Fig. 5 . Ru particles over Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts can be observed, and the average Ru particle sizes are estimated to be 1.7, 1.2 and 1.1 nm, respectively (Fig. S8). Moreover, TEM-EDX mapping of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst was also investigated, as shown in Fig. 5(d). The main particles were derived from Ru metal particles, and Cu metal species were highly dispersed on CeO2 support and Ru metals. These results indicate that these Ru and Cu metal species are located closely. The formation of small Ru metal particles on CeO2 can be attributed to the role of CeO2 [45,46], where metal particles are relatively strongly retained at the oxygen defect sites, which will be due to the redox properties of cerium oxide. In the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, similar small Ru metal particles were formed as in Ru(1)/CeO2, indicating that Ru metals interact with the ceria support in the same way, even in the presence of Cu metal species. Furthermore, a more detailed TEM observation was conducted to observe the structure of the Cu metal species. From the TEM-EDX analyses (Fig. S9), the layered Cu nanoclusters with a width of ∼ 4 nm and a thickness of ∼0.4 nm were observed. Similar layered Cu nanoclusters (width: 1.1 ∼ 1.5 nm, thickness: 0.4 ∼ 0.46 nm (∼bilayer)) were also observed on CeO2 nanorods [50,51], and the layered Cu clusters were formed in the regions where oxygen defect sites are abundant. The interaction between Cu species and the oxygen defect sites of CeO2 is strong due to the high adsorption ability of the defect sites [45,46], and layered Cu nanoclusters and highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles will be formed over CeO2 support. XAS analyses were conducted with Ru catalysts (Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2) after the reaction and reference Ru samples (Ru powder, RuO2 and Ru(acac)3) to clarify the state of metal species in Cu-Ru/CeO2 catalyst. Ru K-edge XANES spectra of these samples are shown in Fig. 6 . The spectra of Cu(n)-Ru(1)/CeO2 (n = 1, 2), Ru(1)/CeO2 and Ru(5)/CeO2 are similar to that of Ru powder (Fig. 6(a), (d)–(g)), indicating that Ru species over these Ru catalysts are in the metallic state during the reaction, which is in good agreement with the results of H2-TPR analyses (Fig. S4). Fig. 7 shows Ru K-edge EXAFS spectra of the above-mentioned Ru catalysts. The Fourier transform of Ru K-edge EXAFS is shown in Fig. 7 (II), and the results of the curve-fitting analyses are shown in Table 9 . The signal due to the Ru-O bond was hardly observed, and only the signal due to the Ru-Ru bond was observed in all the Ru catalysts (Fig. 7(II)-(d)-(g)), which indicates that the Ru species of all Ru catalysts are in the metallic state. These results agree well with those of H2-TPR (Fig. S4) and Ru K-edge XANES (Fig. 6). From the curve-fitting analyses, the coordination number (CN) of the Ru-Ru bond over Ru(5)/CeO2 and Ru(1)/CeO2 are estimated to be 8.1 and 6.2, respectively, which are much smaller than that of Ru powder (CN = 12, Fig. 7(II)-(d),(e) and Table 9). Therefore, the particle sizes of Ru metals are very small (< 2 nm), and the size of the Ru metal particles over Ru(1)/CeO2 is smaller than Ru(5)/CeO2 because of the lower CN value. These results are in good agreement with the results of TEM analyses (Fig. 5). As for the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, an additional signal was observed around 0.2 nm in addition to the signal due to the Ru-Ru bond (Fig. 7(II)-(f),(g)). The curve-fitting analyses of these catalysts with only the Ru-Ru bond are not good (R f ∼ 3). Considering the addition of Cu to Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru-Cu bond formation is possible. The curve-fitting analyses with Ru-Ru and Ru-Cu bonds provided excellent fitting results (R f ∼ 0.3, Table 9). The CNs of Ru-Ru and Ru-Cu in Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst are calculated to be 6.3 and 1.2, respectively, and those of Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 are calculated to be 6.4 and 1.3, respectively. Therefore, Ru species in Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts are in the metallic state and have both the Ru-Ru and Ru-Cu bonds. Cu K-edge XANES spectra of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2 after the reaction and Cu-based reference samples (Cu foil, Cu2O and CuO) are shown in Fig. 8 . The spectra of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 are similar to that of Cu foil, which indicates that Cu species in these catalysts are in the metallic state during the reaction. These results do not conflict with that of H2-TPR analyses (Fig. S4). Fig. 9 shows Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2 catalysts, and the Cu-based reference samples (Cu2O, CuO, and Cu foil). From the FT spectra of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2 catalysts, only the signal due to the Cu-Cu bond was observed, and the signal due to the Cu–O bond was not observed. These results indicate that the Cu species over the catalysts are in the metallic state, which agrees with the results of XANES (Fig. 8) and H2-TPR analyses (Fig. S4). From the curve-fitting analyses (Table 10 ), the CNs of the Cu-Cu bond over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2 catalysts were estimated to be 7.8, 9.8 and 9.8, respectively. From the Cu–Cu CN, Cu metal particles would be expected to be observed by XRD or TEM analyses, however, the signals due to Cu metals over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 were not observed in XRD analyses (Fig. S6), and the layered Cu nanoclusters and highly dispersed Cu particles were observed over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst in TEM analyses (Fig. S9). Therefore, the layered Cu nanoclusters will be mainly formed on the catalyst. In the case of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(2)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts, the Cu-Ru bond was not observed, which is due to the smaller amount of Cu incorporated into the Ru-Cu alloy than the total introduced Cu amount (about 10 %, discussed later). In general, XPS analysis is used to investigate the electronic state of catalyst surfaces. However, in the Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, the particle size is extremely small (∼1 nm). Considering the analysis depth of XPS (generally ∼ 5 nm), the information that would be obtained reflects the entire Ru particle rather than just the surface. Considering that the Cu content in the alloy is very low (∼14 %), the majority is Ru (∼86 %) (Fig. 7 and Table 9), making it difficult for XPS to detect the changes in the electronic state of Ru metals due to Cu. On the other hand, since Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst has Ru-Cu alloys with Cu introduced on the surface, significant changes are expected to be detected at the surface. Therefore, we considered CO adsorption using FTIR, which is effective for analyzing the surface metal state, to be a suitable method. CO adsorption on the catalysts was performed by FT-IR to clarify the surface state of the Ru and Cu metal species. CO was introduced to the reduced Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Cu(1)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and CeO2, and the CO adspecies on the catalysts under CO and Ar flow were measured by FT-IR (Fig. 10 ). Fig. 10(I) shows the FT-IR spectra of the CO adspecies under CO flow, and the spectra were obtained by subtracting the spectrum of gaseous CO from the raw spectra. The signals due to CO adspecies were observed over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2, but not on CeO2. Ru(1)/CeO2 shows the broad signals including three main peaks around 2059, 2029 and 1976 cm−1, and a small signal around 2120 cm−1 (Fig. 10(I)-(b)). Considering that Ru species over Ru(1)/CeO2 are mainly in the metallic state, the former CO adspecies (2059 and 2029 cm−1) are assignable to linear CO, twin-type CO and/or triplet-type CO on Ru metals, and the latter (1976 cm−1) is assignable to bridge CO on Ru metals [52–54]. The small signal around 2120 cm−1 is assignable to twin-type CO and/or triplet-type CO on Ruδ+ species [52–54]. Cu(1)/CeO2 shows one main signal around 2120 cm−1 (Fig. 10(I)-(c)), which was easily desorbed by evacuation (Fig. 10(II)). According to the previous studies on the CO adsorption on Cu/SiO2, the CO adspecies on Cu⁰ are weak and readily desorbed at room temperature by evacuation, whereas CO adsorbed on Cu+ is relatively stable and can be detected [55,56]. Therefore, the signal of 2120 cm−1 is assignable to linear CO on Cu metals. These results indicate that Cu species are reduced to Cu metals, which agrees with the result of H2-TPR and XAS analyses. Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 (Fig. 10(I)-(d)) shows similar signals that were observed on Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)/CeO2, indicating that similar Cu and Ru metals exist on Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2. Focusing on the signal position of CO adspecies on Cu metals, the position of 2120 cm−1 is a higher wavenumber than that (2100 cm−1) on bulk Cu metals [49,57]. The CO adspecies can be assigned to ones on highly dispersed Cu metals according to the previous works on CO adspecies on Cu metals [56,58,59]. These results suggest that the electron density of Cu metals over Cu(1)/CeO2 and Ru(1)-Cu(1)/CeO2 catalysts is lower than that of bulk Cu metals, which implies the strong interaction between CeO2 and Cu metal species. This result will be related to the formation of the layered Cu nanoclusters on CeO2. Fig. 10(II) shows the FT-IR spectra of the CO adspecies under Ar flow after the evacuation of gaseous CO from Fig. 10(I). Cu(1)/CeO2 shows no signal (Fig. 10(II)-(c)), meaning that CO adspecies on Cu metals under CO are equilibrium ones and desorbed by the evacuation. Ru(1)/CeO2 shows a similar spectrum to that under CO (Fig. 10(II)-(b)), although the intensity of the signals around 2029 and 1976 cm−1 decreased to some extent by the evacuation. Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 (Fig. 10(II)-(d)) shows similar signals to that of Ru(1)/CeO2. The intensity of the signals around 2029 and 1976 cm−1 assignable to CO adspecies on the bridge site drastically decreased, which means that the CO adspecies were weakly adsorbed and will be on the Ru and Cu bridge site. The peak of the main signal was observed at 2067 cm−1, which was shifted from the main signal (2059 cm−1) of Ru(1)/CeO2 (Fig. 10(II)-(b), (d)). The blue shift of the signal was caused by the introduction of Cu metals to Ru metals, which can be explained by the electron transfer from Ru metals to Cu metals based on Allred-Rochow electronegativity (Ru: 1.42, Cu: 1.75). These results support the XAS analyses showing that Ru and Cu metals formed Ru-Cu bonds (Fig. 7 and Table 9) and do not contradict the results of H2-TPR and TEM analyses (Figs. S4 and 5). Moreover, the intensity of the signals, namely the signal area, due to CO adspecies over Cu(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 (Fig. 10(II)-(b), (d)) was compared. The intensity over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 is estimated to be 47.6 cm−1, which is about 18 % smaller than that over Cu(1)/CeO2 (57.8 cm−1). These results indicate that the surface Ru metal amount decreased by the addition of Cu metals to Ru metals, and considering the particle size of Ru metals are similar over Cu(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 by TEM analyses (Cu(1)/CeO2: 1.2 nm, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2: 1.1 nm, Fig. 5), Cu metals at least exist on the surface of Ru particles. From the above characterizations such as H2-TPR, XRD, TEM, XAS and CO adsorption by FTIR, the following information of Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts is obtained: Ru(5)/CeO2 has Ru metals, the average Ru particle size is about 1.7 nm. The CN of Ru-Ru is 7.9. Ru(1)/CeO2 has Ru metals, and the average Ru particle size is about 1.2 nm. The CN of Ru-Ru is 6.2. Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 has Ru and Cu metals, the Ru particle size is about 1.1 nm, and Cu metal species are mainly layered nanoclusters with some being highly dispersed. The CNs of Ru-Ru and Ru-Cu are 6.3 and 1.2, and that of Cu-Cu is 9.8. Some Cu species are introduced in Ru metal particles to form the Ru-Cu bonds, and about 18 % of surface Ru metals were decreased by the introduction of Cu metals. Based on these results, the images of the plausible catalyst structures and active sites of Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . The details of the modeling of the metal clusters are shown in the supporting information. The close-packed cluster model with 63 Ru atoms for the active site of Ru(5)/CeO2 (particle size: 1.6 nm and Ru-Ru CN: 7.9) can achieve the above experimental results, such as particle size (1.7 nm) and the CN of Ru-Ru (8.1) (Fig. 11, upper model). The close-packed cluster model with 22 Ru atoms for the active site of Ru(1)/CeO2 (particle size: 1.1 nm and Ru-Ru CN: 6.3) can also achieve the above experimental results, such as particle size (1.2 nm) and the CN of Ru-Ru (6.2) (Fig. 11, middle model). Assuming that all Ru metals are used for the formation of the active site, the close-packed cluster model with 19 Ru and 3 Cu atoms for the active site of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 (particle size: 1.1 nm, Ru-Ru CN: 6.2, Ru-Cu CN: 1.0 and Ru surface coverage rate: 17 %) also reproduces the experimental results such as particle size (1.1 nm), the CN of Ru-Ru (6.3) and Ru-Cu (1.2) and Ru surface coverage rate (18 %) (Fig. 11, lower model). Cu species in Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst exist on the surface of Ru particles, which is reasonable considering the deposition order (Ru → Cu) in the catalyst preparation and the low annealing temperature (573 K) in catalyst pretreatment. Based on the active site model over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, the ratio of Ru/Cu in the Ru-Cu surface alloy is estimated to be 19/3, about 10 % of the Cu metals are used for the alloy, and about 90 % are mainly layered nanoclusters, and some are highly dispersed particles (Fig. 11). Based on the model structures, the ensemble size of each catalyst was estimated. In the model structures of the catalysts, the metal particles are surrounded by seven facets. The Ru ensemble on each facet was evaluated based on the number of Ru atoms, and the average ensemble size per facet was then calculated. Details of the Ru ensemble size estimation method are provided in the Supporting Information. The total gas and methane selectivities in the hydrogenation of LDPE were plotted as a function of the average Ru ensemble size of the catalysts at the point of reaching exactly 100 % conversion (Fig. 12 (a)) and a moderate conversion level (∼60 %, Fig. 12(b)). There are good correlations of the average Ru ensemble size with the total gas and methane selectivities, indicating that the decrease in Ru ensemble size led to a decrease in methane and total gas selectivities. Moreover, the terminal C–C bond cleavage ratio was also plotted as a function of the average Ru ensemble size at the point of reaching exactly 100 % conversion (Fig. 13 (a)) and a moderate conversion level (Fig. 13(b)). The terminal C–C bond cleavage ratio linearly decreased with the decrease in the average Ru ensemble sizes, indicating that smaller Ru ensemble sizes suppressed the terminal C–C bond dissociation. Therefore, it can be concluded that reducing the Ru ensemble size suppresses the cleavage of terminal C–C bonds, thereby inhibiting the formation of gas products, particularly methane. However, it should be noted that the Ru ensemble sizes used here are average values calculated from the estimated catalyst structures. Considering the possibility that the substrate may simultaneously adsorb on different surfaces or diffuse, a more detailed investigation is needed to clarify the precise relationship between active Ru ensemble size and gas selectivity. The plausible C–C bond dissociation mechanisms of polyethylenes over these Ru catalysts are shown in Scheme 1 , according to the previous works on the hydrogenolysis of alkanes over Ru/CeO2 [60]. Scheme 1(A) shows the plausible reaction mechanism over the Ru/CeO2 catalyst. The C–C bond dissociation starts with the adsorption of alkyl chains on a Ru atom via the C–H bond dissociation (Scheme 1(A)-(i)). Next, the C–C bond dissociation over two adjacent Ru atoms produces two alkyl adspecies (Scheme 1(A)-(ii)), where the alkyl adspecies can easily migrate over the surface of Ru metals. The H2 is dissociatively adsorbed on Ru atoms to produce H atoms (Scheme 1(A)-(iii)). If H2 is adequately supplied to the catalyst surface, the hydrogenation of the alkyl species smoothly occurs to form alkanes (less methane products) (Scheme 1(A)-(iv)). However, if H2 is not supplied adequately, consecutive C–C bond dissociation occurs with adjacent Ru atoms (Scheme 1(A)-(v)), followed by hydrogenation to produce a large amount of methane. When the Ru particle size decreases, the ensemble of Ru atoms decreases, and the consecutive C–C bond dissociation in step (v) is suppressed, leading to low methane formation. The mechanism can explain the low methane yield over Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst (Ru particle size: 1.2 nm) compared with Ru(5)/CeO2 catalyst (Ru particle size: 1.7 nm) (Figs. 2 and 12). Scheme 1(B) shows the plausible mechanism over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst. The reaction steps (i) and (ii) are the same as those of Ru/CeO2 (Scheme 1(A)). The H2 is dissociatively adsorbed on Ru or Cu atoms to produce H atoms (Scheme 1(B)-(iii)). Since Cu metals are incorporated in Ru metals, namely Ru ensemble decreases, the consecutive C–C bond dissociation over two adjacent Ru atoms is difficult. Therefore, the hydrogenation of the alkyl species proceeds to produce alkanes (Scheme 1(B)-(iv)), leading to the suppression of methane formation, as shown in Fig. 2. Moreover, in the case of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, the formation of other gas products such as ethane, propane and butane was also suppressed similarly (Figs. 2, 12, 13), which will be due to the low reactivity of shorter alkanes compared with longer alkanes over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst. One possible explanation for the reactivity change by the addition of Cu metals to Ru/CeO2 is as follows: The polyethylene, longer alkanes, are adsorbed on the catalyst surface through intermolecular interactions with CeO2, such as hydrogen bonding and metal-C bond formation with Ru metals. In the case of Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst, Ru metal sites are partially replaced with copper, and the adsorption of the alkyl chains of polyethylenes on metal particles is weakened because the Cu-C bond is generally weaker than the Ru-C bond [61]. The adsorption energy of shorter alkanes on the catalyst surface decreases more significantly than that of longer alkanes. Therefore, the reaction of longer alkanes proceeds preferably, resulting in low gas products. 5 Conclusions We found that 1 wt% Cu- and 1 wt% Ru-supported on CeO2, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, was an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of LDPE, providing valuable chemicals such as liquid chemicals (C5-C21) and waxes (C22 and more) in 96 % yield by suppressing the formation of gas products (C1–C4, 4.3 % yield (CH4: 2.3 %)). Low gas selectivity with high conversion was demonstrated even at a low-pressure condition of 2 MPa. Moreover, the catalyst is applicable to the reaction of various polyethylenes such as LDPE, HDPE and LLDPE with various molecular weights. From various characterizations of Ru(5)/CeO2, Ru(1)/CeO2 and Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalysts such as XRD, TEM, TEM-EDX, H2-TPR, XAS and CO adsorption by FT-IR, the active site structures were clarified. Ru(1)/CeO2 has smaller Ru particles than that of Ru(5)/CeO2 (Ru(1)/CeO2: 1.2 nm, Ru(5)/CeO2: 1.7 nm), resulting in smaller Ru ensemble. Moreover, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 has metal particles similar to that of Ru(1)/CeO2 and forms a Ru-Cu surface alloy, leading to the decreased Ru ensemble. This decrease of Ru ensemble over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst suppresses the consecutive C–C bond dissociation, resulting in the low methane yield. This catalyst system proposes a novel catalyst design based on the surface alloying of inexpensive Cu with Ru, providing a design strategy for suppressing methane formation. coredata.dc:description: Chemical recycling of polyolefins to valuable chemicals has a high potential to mitigate plastic problems and contributes to carbon recycling. In the previous works, we reported that CeO2- and ZrO2-supported Ru (Ru/CeO2 and Ru/ZrO2) catalysts were effective for the hydrogenolysis of polyolefins such as PE, PP, and even waste PE plastics; however, the gas products were formed in ∼10 % yield. The development of effective heterogeneous catalysts that can suppress the formation of cheap gas products, particularly methane, through the incorporation of inexpensive metals into Ru is highly required to achieve high yields of valuable chemicals such as liquid and waxes. Herein, we found that 1 wt% Cu doped 1 wt% Ru/CeO2, Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2, was an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the suppression of the methane formation (2.3 %, C1–C4 gas: ∼4%) at >99 % conversion in the hydrogenolysis of LDPE at 5 MPa H2, providing the high yield (96 %) of the valuable chemicals (liquid chemicals (C5-C21) + waxes (C ≥22)). The gas selectivity remains low even at a low H2 pressure of 2 MPa. Based on the catalyst characterizations such as XRD, TEM, TEM-EDX, H2-TPR, XAS, and FT-IR analyses, the size of the active metal particles over Cu(1)-Ru(1)/CeO2 catalyst is about 1 nm, and the addition of Cu metal into Ru/CeO2 formed Ru-Cu surface alloy on the Ru particles. The formation of the small metal particles and Cu-Ru surface alloy by the addition of inexpensive Cu to Ru decreased the Ru ensemble size to suppress the consecutive C–C bond dissociation of LDPE, leading to low methane and gas yields.
